# B Explicit Form of Operators and Structures 

For Lorentzian signature, after Fourier transformation, denoting 1-form $A=\left(A_{t}, A_{x}, A_{y}\right)^{T}$ and 2-form $d_{1} A=\left(\left(d_{1} A\right)_{x y},\left(d_{1} A\right)_{y t},\left(d_{1} A\right)_{t x}\right)^{T}=\left(\left(d_{1} A\right)^{t},\left(d_{1} A\right)^{x},\left(d_{1} A\right)^{y}\right)^{T}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& d_{0}(q)=\left[\begin{array}{c}
e^{i q_{t}}-1 \\
e^{i q_{x}}-1 \\
e^{i q_{y}}-1
\end{array}\right] \\
& d_{1}(q)=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
0 & -e^{i q_{y}}+1 & e^{i q_{x}}-1 \\
e^{i q_{y}}-1 & 0 & -e^{i q_{t}}+1 \\
-e^{i q_{x}}+1 & e^{i q_{t}}-1 & 0
\end{array}\right] \\
& d_{2}(q)=\left[e^{i q_{t}}-1 e^{i q_{x}}-1 e^{i q_{y}}-1\right] \\
& \eta=\left[\begin{array}{c}
(1-i \epsilon) c^{2} \\
-(1+i \epsilon) \\
\cdots \quad-(1+i \epsilon)
\end{array}\right] \\
& \cup(q)=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
e^{i q_{t}} & 0 & 0 \\
0 & e^{i q_{x}} & 0 \\
0 & 0 & e^{i q_{y}}
\end{array}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that $q_{t}=-q^{t}=-\omega$. When calculating the specturum of classical EoM, the $i \epsilon$ prescription in $\eta$ will be neglected. For Euclidean signature, $q_{t}$ becomes $q_{\tau}=q^{\tau}$, and $\eta$ becomes

$$
\eta_{\mathrm{E}}=\left[\begin{array}{ll}
c^{2} & \\
& 1 \\
& 1
\end{array}\right]
$$

(the $i \epsilon$ prescription in the Lorentzian $\eta$ is just $-i \epsilon \eta_{\mathrm{E}}$ ) where we will mostly take $c^{2}=1$ when working with Euclidean signature.

In our Fourier transformation, if we choose the coordinate of other points on a link (such as its middle point) to label the link, the Fourier transformed link variable will differ by some matrix action $T_{1}$ on its left; similarly the Fourier transformed plaquette variable will change by some $T_{2}$. We have
$S=\frac{1}{V} \sum_{k}-\frac{1}{2 e^{2}}\left(A^{\dagger} T_{1}^{\dagger}\right)\left(T_{1} d_{1}^{\dagger} T_{2}^{\dagger}\right)\left(T_{2} \eta T_{2}^{\dagger}\right)\left(T_{2} d_{1} T_{1}^{\dagger}\right)\left(T_{1} A\right)+\frac{k}{4 \pi}\left(A^{\dagger} T_{1}^{\dagger}\right)\left(T_{1} \cup T_{2}^{\dagger}\right)\left(T_{2} d_{1} T_{1}^{\dagger}\right)\left(T_{1} A\right)$.

So $M$ will transform to $T_{1}^{\dagger} M T_{1}$. Since the transformation is unitary, the eigenvalues will not change.

## C Proof of the Ansatz Eq. (4.2)

From the picture Fig. 5 we can see the EoM $\left(i K d_{1} A\right)^{t, x}\left(\omega, q_{x}, y\right)=0$ only involves $d_{1} A$ at $y$ and $y-1$, while $\left(i K d_{1} A\right)^{y}\left(\omega, q_{x}, y\right)=0$ only involves $d_{1} A$ at $y$ and $y+1$ (recall that

links and plaquettes are labeled by the point with smallest $y$ ). So both lines of Eq. (4.1) only involve $d_{1} A$ at $y$ and $y-1$, and therefore Eq. (4.1) can be recognized as a first-order linear recurrence relation, i.e. transfer matrix equation,

$$
R\left(\omega, q_{x}\right)\left(d_{1} A\right)\left(\omega, q_{x}, y\right)-T\left(\omega, q_{x}\right)\left(d_{1} A\right)\left(\omega, q_{x}, y-1\right)=0 \quad \forall y>0
$$

where $R, T$ are some $3 \times 3$ matrices independent of $y$. Therefore

$$
\left(d_{1} A\right)\left(\omega, q_{x}, y\right)=\left[\left(R^{-1} T\right)\left(\omega, q_{x}\right)\right]^{y}\left(d_{1} A\right)\left(\omega, q_{x}, 0\right) \quad \forall y \geq 0
$$

(Here the $y$ superscript is the power to the integer $y$, not the $y$ component index.) This means we can diagonalize $R^{-1} T$ and find solutions that decompose $d_{1} A$ into eigenmodes

$$
\left(d_{1} A\right)\left(\omega, q_{x}, y\right)=\sum_{q_{y}} e^{i q_{y} y}\left(d_{1} A\right)\left(\omega, q_{x}, q_{y}\right)
$$

where, naively, the summation is over all three eigenvalues $e^{i q_{y}}$ of the $3 \times 3$ matrix $\left(R^{-1} T\right)\left(\omega, q_{x}\right)$. However, because $d_{2} d_{1} A=0$, we can say $d_{1} A$ really only has two rather than three independent components (just like in the continuum, given $E_{x}$ and $E_{y}$, we have $B=$ $\left.\left(q_{x} E_{y}-q_{y} E_{x}\right) / \omega\right)$, and the matrix equation is essentially $2 \times 2$. Moreover, according to the discussion below Eq. (4.4), out of the two remaining modes, we have two possibilities: Depending on $\omega, q_{x}$, either we have two modes both with $\left|e^{i q_{y}}\right|=1$, which are the bulk modes that we have already seen in Section 3; or we have a decaying mode with $\left|e^{i q_{y}}\right|<1$, which is the edge mode we are interested in, and a diverging mode with $\left|e^{i q_{y}}\right|>1$, which we will discard.

After having this transfer matrix picture in mind and confirming the validity of the ansatz Eq. (4.2), it turns out we do not need to actually write out the details of $R$ and $T$. We can just work with $K$ as in the main text to solve for the decaying mode $e^{i q_{y}}$ in the ansatz Eq. (4.2).

# D Torsion in Homology and Cohomology, and Reidemeister Torsion 

In this appendix we review the torsion in homology and cohomology. Although the threetorus we consider in the main text has trivial torsion, we believe it is still helpful to have the more general cases in mind, especially for the purpose of understanding the Jacobians of the exterior derivatives and the Reidemeister torsion.

When calculating homology and cohomology groups of a topological space, we can use different kinds of coefficient. $\mathbb{Z}$ and $\mathbb{R}$ are the most commonly used choices. Take the homology case for example. One may naively expect they are essentially the same, and the difference is just changing from some $\mathbb{Z}^{b_{i}}$ to $\mathbb{R}^{b_{i}}$ where $b_{i}$ is the $i$ th Betti number. However, (co)homology groups in coefficient $\mathbb{Z}$ contain something more. They are the torsion part of (co)homology groups. A basic example is $\mathbb{R} P^{3}$ (the topological space of $S O(3)$ ), where each point represents a straight line through 0 in $\mathbb{R}^{4}$; more intuitively, we can picture it as a $3 d$ ball $D^{3}$ but with antipodal points on the $S^{2}$ surface identified. This topological space can be triangulated as Fig. 23. It turns out the first homology group $H_{1}\left(\mathbb{R} P^{3} ; \mathbb{Z}\right)$ contains

torsion: we can calculate it as $H_{1}\left(\mathbb{R} P^{3}\right)=\mathbb{Z}(l) / \mathbb{Z}(\partial \sigma=2 l)=\mathbb{Z} / 2 \mathbb{Z}$. While if we use $\mathbb{R}$ as coefficient, we get $H_{1}\left(\mathbb{R} P^{2} ; \mathbb{R}\right)=\mathbb{R}(l) / \mathbb{R}(\partial \sigma=2 l)=0$ because 2 has an inverse in $\mathbb{R}$ (but not in $\mathbb{Z}$ ). In general, a $\mathbb{Z}$ coefficient homology group is a direct sum of a "torsion part" and a "free part", where the "torsion part" is some finite abelian group, while the "free part" is some infinite abelian group of the form $\mathbb{Z}^{b_{i}}$. The $\mathbb{R}$ coefficient homology only sees the free part $\mathbb{R}^{b_{i}}$.
![img-25.jpeg](img-25.jpeg)

Figure 23: Triangulation of $\mathbb{R} P^{3}$
Torsion will also show up in the cohomology, through the universal coefficient theorem, which says there is a short exact sequence

$$
0 \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(H_{i-1}(M ; \mathbb{Z}), A\right) \longrightarrow H^{i}(M ; A) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Hom}\left(H_{i}(M ; \mathbb{Z}), A\right) \longrightarrow 0
$$

where $A$ is any coefficient group. For $A=\mathbb{Z}$, the Ext part basically counts the torsion part of $H_{i-1}$, while the Hom part counts the free part of $H_{i}$. For $A=\mathbb{R}$, the Ext part becomes trivial.

Now, let us see in general where the torsion may show up for an orientable 3d manifold $M$. For orientable manifold, we have a further constraint $H^{3-i}(M ; \mathbb{Z}) \cong H_{i}(M ; \mathbb{Z})$ from the Poincare duality. Now we consider $i=0,1,2,3$. We know $H_{0}(M ; \mathbb{Z})$ just counts how many connected components $M$ has, so it is torsion free, and hence so is $H^{3}(M ; \mathbb{Z})$. On the other hand, $\cong H^{2}(M ; \mathbb{Z})$, and we have already seen through an example that here might contain non-trivial torsion. And for $H_{2}(M ; \mathbb{Z}) \cong H^{1}(M ; \mathbb{Z})$, using the universal coefficient theorem, we have a short exact sequence

$$
0 \longrightarrow \operatorname{Ext}^{1}\left(H_{0}(M ; \mathbb{Z}), \mathbb{Z}\right) \longrightarrow H^{1}(M ; \mathbb{Z}) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Hom}\left(H_{1}(M ; \mathbb{Z}), \mathbb{Z}\right) \longrightarrow 0
$$

which implies

$$
H^{1}(M ; \mathbb{Z}) \cong \operatorname{Hom}\left(H_{1}(M ; \mathbb{Z}), \mathbb{Z}\right)
$$

because $H_{0}(M ; \mathbb{Z})$ contains no torsion. The torsion part in $H_{1}(M)$ will not contribute to $\operatorname{Hom}\left(H_{1}(M ; \mathbb{Z}), \mathbb{Z}\right)$, so $H_{2}(M ; \mathbb{Z}) \cong H^{1}(M ; \mathbb{Z})$ is also torsion free. As for $H_{3}(M, \mathbb{Z}) \cong$ $H^{0}(M ; \mathbb{Z})$, using the universal coefficient theorem, again we get

$$
H^{0}(M ; \mathbb{Z}) \cong \operatorname{Hom}\left(H_{0}(M ; \mathbb{Z}), \mathbb{Z}\right)
$$

which is torsion free. So the only possible place any torsion may show up is in $H_{1}(M ; \mathbb{Z}) \cong$ $H^{2}(M ; \mathbb{Z})$, and we call the torsion part $\mathcal{T}$.

It seems with $\mathbb{R}$ coefficient cochains, we will just loss the information about torsion. But the information about torsion will show up in a more subtle way, through the Jacobians of the (continuum or lattice) exterior derivatives. The Reidemeister torsion for a 3d lattice $\mathcal{M}$ (the generalization to other dimensions is obvious) is
$R=\frac{d_{2}\left(V_{C^{2} / Z^{2}}\right) \wedge V_{H^{3}}}{V_{C^{3}}} \frac{V_{C^{2}}}{V_{C^{2} / Z^{2}} \wedge d_{1}\left(V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}}\right) \wedge V_{H^{2}}} \frac{V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}} \wedge d_{0}\left(V_{C^{0} / H^{0}}\right) \wedge V_{H^{1}}}{V_{C^{1}}} \frac{V_{C^{0}}}{V_{C^{0} / H^{0}} \wedge V_{H^{0}}}$,
(an analogous continuum definition is called the Ray-Singer torsion, which turns out equal to the Reidemeister torsion $[28,29])$ where $V_{W}$ denotes a volume form of the vector space $W$, all the cohomology here are evaluated with coefficient $\mathbb{R}$ and we drop the $(\mathcal{M} ; \mathbb{R})$ label for all the vector spaces. The notation $d_{0}\left(V_{C^{0} / H^{0}}\right)$ is the volume form of its image $B^{1}$ obtained by applying $d_{0}$ to a volume form of its coimage $C^{0} / H^{0}$. As we can see, the value of $R$ depends on the choice of $V_{H^{i}}, V_{C^{i}}$, but the dependence on the choice of $V_{C^{i} / Z^{i}}$ is cancelled out-the crucial reason why $R$ is defined in such a way. On a lattice, we do have a nature choice of basis for $C^{i}$, and for $V_{H^{i}}$, we can choose the basis corresponding to the embedding of the basis for free part in $\mathbb{Z}$-valued cohomology groups.

Consider $\mathbb{R} P^{3}$ as an example. Using the triangulation in Fig. 23, a straight forward calculation tells us the Reidemeister torsion of $\mathbb{R} P^{3}$ is

$$
R=\frac{e_{c}}{e_{c}} \frac{e_{\sigma}}{2 e_{\sigma}} \frac{e_{l}}{e_{l}} \frac{e_{v}}{e_{v}}=\frac{1}{2}=\frac{1}{\left|\mathbb{Z}_{2}\right|}
$$

where we have $e_{c, \sigma, l, v}$ as the chosen basis. We find $R$ equals to the reciprocal of the torsion size. In fact this is not a coincidence.

Recall that for Eq. (5.6) we have claimed that if we choose the basis for coimage $C^{i} / Z^{i}$ and image $B^{i}$ of $d_{i}$ to be those embedded by the $\mathbb{Z}$-valued spaces, there is no Jacobian, which means under this choice of $V_{C^{i} / Z^{i}}$ and $V_{B^{i}}$ we have $d_{i}\left(V_{C^{i} / Z^{i}}\right)=V_{B^{i+1}}$. The Reidemeister torsion becomes

$$
R=\frac{V_{B^{3}} \wedge V_{H^{3}}}{V_{C^{3}}} \frac{V_{C^{2}}}{V_{C^{2} / Z^{2}} \wedge V_{B^{2}} \wedge V_{H^{2}}} \frac{V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}} \wedge V_{B^{1}} \wedge V_{H^{1}}}{V_{C^{1}}} \frac{V_{C^{0}}}{V_{C^{0} / H^{0}} \wedge V_{H^{0}}}
$$

Now the only difference between denominator and numerator of each factor is the torsion part of $H^{i}(\mathcal{M} ; \mathbb{Z})$, so in the end we get the Reidemeister torsion

$$
|R|=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{T}|}
$$

measuring the size of the torsion.
The Reidemeister torsion and the continuum Ray-Singer torsion can also be defined for covariant derivatives with non-trivial flat gauge fields, and the result is still a topological invariant in a suitable sense. We will not encounter these more general cases in the present work.

# E A More Rigorous Calculation of the Partition Function 

For a general spacetime $M$, each $[s] \in H^{2}(M ; \mathbb{Z}) \cong H_{1}(M ; \mathbb{Z})$ corresponds to a (topological class of) non-contractible loop on the dual lattice, and we have learnt in Appendix D that

they fall into two different categories: those that become contractible after going around the loop a certain number of times, and those that never become contractible this way. We call the first kind the torsion part (isomorphic to some $\bigoplus_{i} \mathbb{Z}_{p_{i}}$, which is finite) and the second kind the free part (isomorphic $\mathbb{Z}^{b_{1}}$ for some integer $b_{1}$, called the first Betti number, which is intuitively "the number of holes"). The integral over $A^{\prime}$ involves flat fluctuations, which take value in $H^{1}(M ; \mathbb{R})$. From the universal coefficient theorem, we know that $H^{1}(M ; \mathbb{R})$ is isomorphic to $\operatorname{Hom}\left(H_{1}(M ; \mathbb{Z}), \mathbb{R}\right)$, in which only the free part of $H_{1}$ gets mapped non-trivially to $\mathbb{R}$. Thus, the flat fluctuation of $A^{\prime}$ serves as a Lagrange multiplier for the free part of $\left[s^{\prime}\right]$ through their cup product of in the action. As a result, the contribution of $\left[s^{\prime}\right]$ vanishes unless the free part of $\left[s^{\prime}\right]$ is trivial. Therefore only the torsion part contributes:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& Z=\frac{\left[\prod_{l} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{d A_{l}^{\prime}}{2 \pi}\right]}{\left[\prod_{v} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{d \phi_{v}^{\prime}}{2 \pi}\right]} \frac{\sum_{[s]}}{\sum_{s^{\prime} \mid v^{\prime}]} \sum_{[s^{\prime} \mid \in \mathcal{T}}} \\
& \left.\left(z_{\chi}\left[\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }}\right]\right)^{k} \exp \left\{-\frac{1}{2 e^{2}} \sum_{p} F_{p}^{2}+\frac{i k}{4 \pi} \sum_{c}\left[\left(A^{\prime} \cup d A^{\prime}\right)_{c}-\left(A^{\prime} \cup 2 \pi\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }}\right)_{c}-\left(2 \pi\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }} \cup A^{\prime}\right)_{c}\right]\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

To eliminate $\left[s^{\prime}\right]$ in $F=d A^{\prime}-2 \pi\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }}$, note that when we map $H^{2}(M ; \mathbb{Z})$ to $H^{2}(M ; \mathbb{R})$, the kernel is the torsion part, since $H^{2}(M ; \mathbb{R})$ has no torsion. This means for $\left[s^{\prime}\right] \in \mathcal{T}$ that satisfies $p\left[s^{\prime}\right]=[0] \in \mathcal{T}$ for some some integer $p$, exists some $A_{\left[s^{\prime}\right] \text { rep }}^{\prime} \in C^{1}(M ; 2 \pi \mathbb{Z} / p)$ such that $d A_{\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }}}^{\prime}=2 \pi\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }}$ (but $A_{\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }}}^{\prime} \notin C^{1}(M ; 2 \pi \mathbb{Z})$ unless $\left[s^{\prime}\right]=[0]$ ), so after a redefinition of $A^{\prime \prime}=A^{\prime}-A_{\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }}}^{\prime}$, we can absorb these $\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }}$, and write $F=d A^{\prime \prime}$. The action becomes

$$
S=-\frac{1}{2 e^{2}} \sum_{p}\left(d A^{\prime \prime}\right)_{p}^{2}+\frac{i k}{4 \pi} \sum_{c}\left[\left(A^{\prime \prime} \cup d A^{\prime \prime}\right)_{c}-\left(2 \pi\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }} \cup A_{\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }}\right)_{c}}^{\prime}\right]
$$

which consists of two independent parts: a free theory for $A_{l}^{\prime \prime} \in \mathbb{R}$, and $-i(k / 2) \sum_{c}\left(\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }}\right.$ $\cup$ $A_{\left[s^{\prime}\right] \text { rep }}^{\prime}\right)_{c}$ which is proportional to the self-linking number $\operatorname{link}\left(\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }},\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }}\right)=\sum_{c}\left(\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }}\right.$ $\cup$ $A_{\left[s^{\prime}\right] \text { rep }}^{\prime} / 2 \pi)_{c}$ of loops in torsion part.

Note the self-linking number of a torsion loop is fractional-suppose $\left[s^{\prime}\right] \in \mathcal{T}$ is such that $p\left[s^{\prime}\right]$ is contractible, then $A_{\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }}}^{\prime}$ is a multiple of $2 \pi / p$, hence the self-linking number is a multiple of $1 / p$. For even $k$, only the fractional part of the self-linking number contributes to the partition function; under change of branching structure (which changes loop framing), the self-linking number only changes by an integer, and thus its contribution to the partition function is unchanged. For odd $k$, under change of branching structure, the change of the self-linking number may contribute an extra $e^{i \pi}$ to the partition function, but this change will always be compensated by the change of $z_{\chi}$.

The free theory part can be calculated by Faddeev-Popov method. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
Z= & \left\lvert\, \frac{1}{\sqrt{\left[(2 \pi)^{-1} M\right]\left(V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}}, V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}}\right)}} \frac{V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}} \wedge d_{0}\left(V_{C^{0} / H^{0}}\right) \wedge V_{H^{1}}^{\prime}}{V_{C^{1}}^{\prime}} \frac{V_{C^{0}}^{\prime}}{V_{C^{0} / H^{0}} \wedge V_{H^{0}}^{\prime}}\right. \\
& {\left[\sum_{\left[s^{\prime}\right] \in \mathcal{T}}\left(z_{\chi}\left[\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\mathrm{rep}}\right]\right)^{k} e^{-\frac{i k}{2} \operatorname{link}\left(\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\mathrm{rep}},\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\mathrm{rep}}\right)}\right] }
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, since $M$ is a bilinear form with null space $Z^{1}$, we use $\left[(2 \pi)^{-1} M\right]\left(V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}}, V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}}\right)$ to denote the product of its non-zero eigenvalues $\operatorname{det}^{\prime}\left[(2 \pi)^{-1} M\right]$ once a basis is chosen on $C^{1} / Z^{1}$. More rigorously, $M$ should be regarded as a linear operator from $C^{1} / Z^{1}$ to the dual linear space $\left(C^{1} / Z^{1}\right)^{*}$. If we pick a basis of $C^{1} / Z^{1}$, we also get its dual basis. Comparing $\left[(2 \pi)^{-1} M\right]\left(V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}}\right)$ with the volume form $V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}}{ }^{*}$ induced by the dual basis, we have

$$
\left[(2 \pi)^{-1} M\right]\left(V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}}, V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}}\right)=\operatorname{det}^{\prime}\left[(2 \pi)^{-1} M\right]=\frac{\left[(2 \pi)^{-1} M\right]\left(V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}}\right)}{V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}}^{*}}
$$

and as the notation suggests, $\left[(2 \pi)^{-1} M\right]\left(\lambda V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}}, \lambda V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}}\right)=\lambda^{2}\left[(2 \pi)^{-1} M\right]\left(V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}}, V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}}\right)$ when scaling the volume form.

Recall that we already have canonical basis for $C^{i}, H^{i}$ as defined in Appendix D. The difference between the canonical volume form $V_{\bullet}$ (here $\bullet$ can only be filled by $C^{i}, H^{i}$ ) and the volume form $V_{\bullet}^{\prime}$ in the path integral measure (i.e. $\prod_{l} \int\left(d A_{l}\right) /(2 \pi)$ and other integrals or summations) is just a $(2 \pi)^{\operatorname{dim} C^{i}}$ or $(2 \pi)^{\operatorname{dim} H^{i}}$ factor. More precisely, the factor is $(2 \pi)^{-\operatorname{dim} C^{1}+\operatorname{dim} C^{0}+\operatorname{dim} H^{1}-\operatorname{dim} H^{0}}=(2 \pi)^{-\operatorname{dim} C^{1} / Z^{1}}$, which can be absorbed by changing $\operatorname{det}^{\prime}\left[(2 \pi)^{-1} M\right]^{-1 / 2}$ to $\operatorname{det}^{\prime}[(2 \pi) M]^{-1 / 2}$.

We continue to define $\operatorname{det}^{\prime}$ for other linear operators. Take $d_{0}$ as an example:

$$
\operatorname{det}^{\prime} d_{0}=\frac{d_{0}\left(V_{C^{0} / H^{0}}\right)}{V_{B^{1}}}
$$

Note that $\operatorname{det}^{\prime}$ depends on a certain choice of volume form of image and coimage space. Now we can write

$$
Z=\left|\frac{\operatorname{det}^{\prime} d_{0}}{\sqrt{\operatorname{det}^{\prime}(2 \pi M)}} \frac{V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}} \wedge V_{B^{1}} \wedge V_{H^{1}}}{V_{C^{1}}} \frac{V_{C^{0}}}{V_{C^{0} / H^{0}} \wedge V_{H^{0}}}\right|\left[\sum_{\left[s^{\prime}\right] \in \mathcal{T}}\left(z_{\chi}\left[\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\mathrm{rep}}\right]\right)^{k} e^{-\frac{i k}{2} \operatorname{link}\left(\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\mathrm{rep}},\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\mathrm{rep}}\right)}\right]
$$

We would like to calculate $Z$ in two ways: one is to use the Fourier basis and give a precise meaning of Eq. (5.10); the other is to use the Poincare duality and extract a factor of $\sqrt{|R|}$ to arrive at Eq. (5.13).

Consider the $\mathbb{T}^{3}$ lattice $\mathbb{Z}_{L_{r}} \times \mathbb{Z}_{L_{x}} \times \mathbb{Z}_{L_{y}}$. For $C^{0}$, we use the Fourier basis $\phi(r)=e^{i q r} / \mathcal{V}$ (where $\mathcal{V}=L_{r} L_{x} L_{y}$ ) with $q \neq 0$ for $C^{0} / H^{0}$ and an additional basis vector $\phi(r)=1$ for $H^{0}$. One may wonder why we do not simply use $\phi(r)=1 / \mathcal{V}$ for $q=0$ as well, and this can be traced back to how we introduced these $q=0$ trivial gauge transformations in the first

place-we introduced them as the embedding of $[\kappa] \in H^{0}\left(\mathbb{T}^{3}, \mathbb{Z}\right)$ into $H^{0}\left(\mathbb{T}^{3}, \mathbb{R}\right)$ (which is what we call $H^{0}$ now; recall the $2 \pi$ 's has been absorbed before).

Similarly, for $C^{1}$, we use the basis $A(r)=(1,0,0)^{T} e^{i q r} / \mathcal{V}, A(r)=(0,1,0)^{T} e^{i q r} / \mathcal{V}$ and $A(r)=(0,0,1)^{T} e^{i q r} / \mathcal{V}$ with $q \neq 0$ for $C^{1} / H^{1}$, and, instead of the usual $q=0$ basis, we use $A(r)=(1,0,0)^{T} \delta_{\tau, 0}, A(r)=(0,1,0)^{T} \delta_{x, 0}$ or $A(r)=(0,0,1)^{T} \delta_{y, 0}$ for $H^{1}$, which are the embedding of $[n] \in H^{1}\left(\mathbb{T}^{3}, \mathbb{Z}\right)$ into $H^{0}\left(\mathbb{T}^{3}, \mathbb{R}\right)$ (which is what we call $H^{1}$ now).

Let us first sort out the Jacobians carefully. For $C^{0}$, if we have used the Fourier basis not only for $q \neq 0$ but also for $q=0$, then we would have the Jacobians

$$
\frac{V_{C^{0}}}{V_{C^{0}, \text { Fourier }}}=\mathcal{V}^{\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{dim} C^{0}}
$$

(If the orthonormal Fourier basis-that with $\sqrt{\mathcal{V}}$ in the denominator-is used instead, this Jacobian would become 1.) However, instead of the $q=0$ Fourier basis, we actually use the embedded basis for $H^{0}$, so there is an extra Jacobian

$$
\frac{V_{C^{0}}}{V_{C^{0}} / H^{0}, \text { Fourier }} \wedge V_{H^{0}}}=\mathcal{V}^{\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{dim} C^{0}-1}
$$

(If for $C^{0} / H^{0}$ the orthonormal Fourier basis is used instead, this Jacobian will become $\mathcal{V}^{-1 / 2}$.)

Similarly, for $C^{1}$, if we have used the Fourier basis not only for $q \neq 0$ but also for $q=0$, then we have the Jacobian

$$
\frac{V_{C^{1}}}{V_{C^{1}, \text { Fourier }}}=\mathcal{V}^{\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{dim} C^{1}}
$$

(If the orthonormal Fourier basis is used instead, the Jacobian will be 1.) But our modified basis has the embedded basis replacing the $q=0$ components of the Fourier basis. To find the extra Jacobian, we decompose the embedded basis as

$$
\left[\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0 \\
0
\end{array}\right] \delta_{\tau, 0}=\sum_{q=0}\left[\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0 \\
0
\end{array}\right] L_{x} L_{y} \frac{1}{\mathcal{V}} e^{i q r}+\sum_{q \neq 0}\left[\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0 \\
0
\end{array}\right] L_{x} L_{y} \delta_{q_{x}, 0} \delta_{q_{y}, 0} \frac{1}{\mathcal{V}} e^{i q r}
$$

and the extra Jacobian is extracted from the $q=0$ coefficient, which is $L_{x} L_{y}$. (If the orthonormal Fourier basis is used instead, the factor will be $L_{x} L_{y} / \sqrt{\mathcal{V}}$.) Similar for other two directions. Therefore

$$
\frac{V_{C^{1}}}{V_{C^{1}} / H^{1}, \text { Fourier }} \wedge V_{H^{1}}}=\mathcal{V}^{\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{dim} C^{1}-2}
$$

(If for $C^{1} / H^{1}$ the orthonormal Fourier basis is used instead, this Jacobian will become $\mathcal{V}^{-1 / 2}$.)

Under the basis transformation $\operatorname{det}^{\prime}(2 \pi M)$ also transforms:

$$
\operatorname{det}^{\prime}(2 \pi M)^{-1 / 2}=\prod_{q \neq 0} \operatorname{det}^{\prime}(2 \pi M(q) / \mathcal{V})^{-1 / 2}=\mathcal{V}^{\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{dim} C^{1}-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{dim} Z^{1}} \prod_{q \neq 0} \operatorname{det}^{\prime}(2 \pi M(q))^{-1 / 2}
$$

where the $1 / \mathcal{V}$ factor in $M$ comes from the fact

$$
\sum_{x} \sum_{y} A(x) M(x-y) A(y)=\frac{1}{\mathcal{V}} \sum_{q} A(-q) M(q) A(q)
$$

(If the orthonormal Fourier basis is used instead, no $\mathcal{V}$ factor will appear here.)
So we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
Z & =\left|\prod_{q \neq 0} \frac{\operatorname{det}^{\prime} d_{0}(q)}{\sqrt{\operatorname{det}^{\prime}(2 \pi M(q))}} \frac{V_{\left(C^{1} / Z^{1}\right)(q)} \wedge V_{B^{1}(q)}}{V_{\left(C^{1} / H^{1}\right)(q), \text { Fourier }}}\right| \mathcal{V}_{\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{dim} C^{1}-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{dim} Z^{1}-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{dim} C^{1}+2+\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{dim} C^{0}-1} \\
& {\left[\sum_{[\mathrm{s}^{\prime}] \in \mathcal{T}}\left(z_{\chi}\left[\left[\mathrm{s}^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }}\right]\right)^{k} e^{-\frac{i k}{2} \operatorname{link}\left[\left[\mathrm{s}^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }},\left[\mathrm{s}^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }}\right)}\right]} \\
& =\left|\prod_{q \neq 0} \frac{\operatorname{det}^{\prime} d_{0}(q)}{\sqrt{\operatorname{det}^{\prime}(2 \pi M(q))}} \frac{V_{\left(C^{1} / Z^{1}\right)(q)} \wedge V_{B^{1}(q)}}{V_{\left(C^{1} / H^{1}\right)(q), \text { Fourier }}}\right|\left[\sum_{[\mathrm{s}^{\prime}] \in \mathcal{T}}\left(z_{\chi}\left[\left[\mathrm{s}^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }}\right]\right)^{k} e^{-\frac{i k}{2} \operatorname{link}\left[\left[\mathrm{s}^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }},\left[\mathrm{s}^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }}\right)}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where $V_{\left(C^{1} / Z^{1}\right)(q)}$ and $V_{\left(B^{1}\right)(q)}$ are volume form for $\left(C^{1} / Z^{1}\right)(q), B^{1}(q)$ which are spanned by vectors in $C^{1} / Z^{1}, B^{1}$ with momentum $q$ (since $d_{i}$ can be decomposed into direct sum of $d_{i}(q)$, this decomposition of $C^{1} / Z^{1}, B^{1}$ is valid) and $M(q)$ is a $3 \times 3$ matrix while $d_{0}(q)$ is a $3 \times 1$ row vector. Notice that all the $\mathcal{V}$ factors cancel out as expected.

We are now very close to the expression Eq. (5.10). Observe that $M(q)$ is a hermitian matrix since $M$ is symmetric and real. So we can use a unitary transformation to diagonalize it. We also know that $d_{0}(q) / \sqrt{\left(d_{0}(q)\right)^{t} d_{0}(q)}$ is one of its normalized eigenvectors, which actually belongs to $M(q)$ 's kernel. Now we may choose $V_{B^{1}(q)}$ basis to be $d_{0}(q) / \sqrt{\left(d_{0}(q)\right)^{t} d_{0}(q)}$, and the other two normalized eigenvectors of $M(q)$ as basis of $C^{1} / Z^{1}(q)$. Thus in the end we have

$$
Z=\left|\prod_{q \neq 0} \frac{\sqrt{\left(d_{0}(q)\right)^{t} d_{0}(q)}}{\sqrt{\operatorname{det}^{\prime}(2 \pi M(q))}}\right|\left[\sum_{[\mathrm{s}^{\prime}] \in \mathcal{T}}\left(z_{\chi}\left[\left[\mathrm{s}^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }}\right]\right)^{k} e^{-\frac{i k}{2} \operatorname{link}\left[\left[\mathrm{s}^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }},\left[\mathrm{s}^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }}\right)}\right]
$$

where $\operatorname{det}^{\prime}(2 \pi M(q))$ just means the product of $M(q)$ 's non-zero eigenvalue. This gives the precise meaning of Eq. (5.10): since $M(q)$ is the the matrix elements under orthonormal Fourier basis for $M$, when using the canonical basis, no Jacobian shows up and the product of all non-zero eigenvalues of $2 \pi M$ matrix in canonical basis is $\operatorname{det}^{\prime}(2 \pi M)=$ $\prod_{q \neq 0} \operatorname{det}^{\prime}(2 \pi M(q))$ while $\prod_{q \neq 0} \sqrt{\left(d_{0}(q)\right)^{t} d_{0}(q)}=\sqrt{\operatorname{det}^{\prime}\left(d_{0}^{T} d_{0}\right)}$.

Now we show how to extract a factor of $\sqrt{|R|}$ from $Z$ to arrive at Eq. (5.13). Going back to Eq. (E.6), we can identify dual spaces $\left(C^{i}\right)^{*},\left(B^{i}\right)^{*},\left(H^{i}\right)^{*}$ with $C_{i}, C_{i} / Z_{i}, H_{i}$ respectively. Using the corresponding dual volume form, we have

$$
\operatorname{det}^{\prime} d_{0}=\frac{d_{0}\left(V_{C^{0} / H^{0}}\right)}{V_{B^{1}}}=\frac{V_{B^{1}}^{*}}{\left(d_{0}\left(V_{C^{0} / H^{0}}\right)\right)^{*}}=\frac{d_{0}^{T}\left(V_{B^{1}}^{*}\right)}{V_{C^{0} / H^{0}}^{*}}=\frac{\left(\partial_{1}\right)\left(V_{C_{1} / Z_{1}}\right)}{V_{B_{0}}}=\operatorname{det}^{\prime}\left(\partial_{1}\right)
$$

where we have the corresponding dual volume form denoted as $V_{\bullet}^{*}$. We also have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}} \wedge V_{B^{1}} \wedge V_{H^{1}}}{V_{C^{1}}} \frac{V_{C^{0}}}{V_{C^{0} / H^{0}} \wedge V_{H^{0}}} \\
& =\frac{V_{C^{1}}^{*}}{V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}}^{*} \wedge V_{B^{1}}^{*} \wedge V_{H^{1}}^{*}} \frac{V_{C^{0} / H^{0}}^{*} \wedge V_{H^{0}}^{*}}{V_{C^{0}}^{*}} \\
& =\frac{V_{C_{1}}}{V_{B_{1}} \wedge V_{C_{1} / Z_{1}} \wedge V_{H_{1}}} \frac{V_{B_{0}} \wedge V_{H_{0}}}{V_{C_{0}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

The partition function can be written as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& Z=\sum_{\left[s^{\prime}\right] \in \mathcal{T}}\left(z_{\chi}\left[\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }}\right]\right)^{k} e^{-S\left[A_{\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }}\right]}} \\
& \sqrt{\left|\frac{\operatorname{det}^{\prime} d_{0} \operatorname{det}^{\prime} \partial_{1}}{\operatorname{det}^{\prime}(2 \pi M)} \frac{V_{C_{1}}}{V_{B_{1}} \wedge V_{C_{1} / Z_{1}} \wedge V_{H_{1}}} \frac{V_{B_{0}} \wedge V_{H_{0}}}{V_{C_{0}}} \frac{V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}} \wedge V_{B^{1}} \wedge V_{H^{1}}}{V_{C^{1}}} \frac{V_{C^{0}}}{V_{C^{0} / H^{0}} \wedge V_{H^{0}}}\right|}
\end{aligned}
$$

On a cubic lattice, we know the dual lattice is isomorphic to the origin lattice. So we have Poincare duality: $C_{i} \cong C^{3-i}, B_{i} \cong B^{3-i}, Z_{i} \cong Z^{3-i}, H_{i} \cong H^{3-i}$. The partition function can be further simplified as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& Z=\sum_{\left[s^{\prime}\right] \in T}\left|\frac{1}{\sqrt{\operatorname{det}^{\prime}(2 \pi K)}}\right|\left(z_{\chi}\left[\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }}\right]\right)^{k} e^{-S\left[A_{\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }}\right]}} \\
& \sqrt{\left|\frac{\operatorname{det}^{\prime}\left(-d_{2}\right) \operatorname{det}^{\prime} d_{0}}{\operatorname{det}^{\prime} d_{1}} \frac{V_{B^{3}} \wedge V_{H^{3}}}{V_{C^{3}}} \frac{V_{C^{2}}}{V_{C^{2} / Z^{2}} \wedge V_{B^{2}} \wedge V_{H^{2}}} \frac{V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}} \wedge V_{B^{1}} \wedge V_{H^{1}}}{V_{C^{1}}} \frac{V_{C^{0}}}{V_{C^{0} / H^{0}} \wedge V_{H^{0}}}\right|} \\
& =\sum_{\left[s^{\prime}\right] \in T}\left|\frac{\sqrt{R}}{\sqrt{\operatorname{det}^{\prime}(2 \pi K)}}\right|\left(z_{\chi}\left[\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }}\right]\right)^{k} e^{-S\left[A_{\left[s^{\prime}\right]^{\text {rep }}\right]}},
\end{aligned}
$$

where we have factorized $M=K d_{1}$ to extract the Reidemeister torsion $R$. Here $\operatorname{det}^{\prime}(2 \pi K)=$ $(2 \pi K)\left(V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}}, V_{B^{2}}\right)$, and since we have used the Poincare duality, if we have chosen a basis for $B^{2}$, then it induces a basis for $C_{2} / Z_{2} \cong C^{1} / Z^{1}$. And notice that when changing the basis

$$
\frac{V_{B^{2}}^{\prime}}{V_{B^{2}}}=\frac{V_{C_{2} / Z_{2}}}{V_{C_{2} / Z_{2}}^{\prime}}=\frac{V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}}}{V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}}^{\prime}}
$$

which indicates that the $(2 \pi K)\left(V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}}^{\prime}, V_{B^{2}}^{\prime}\right)=(2 \pi K)\left(V_{C^{1} / Z^{1}}, V_{B^{2}}\right)$ is a deterministic number regardless of the choice of basis.

# References

abstract:
We define and solve the $\text{U(1)}$ Chern-Simons-Maxwell theory on
spacetime lattice, with an emphasis on the chirality of the theory. Realizing
Chern-Simons theory on lattice has been a problem of interest for decades, and
over the years it has gradually become clear that there are two key points: 1)
Some non-topological term, such as a Maxwell term, is necessary -- this is true
even in the continuum, but more manifestly on the lattice; 2) the $\text{U(1)}$
gauge field should be implemented in the Villainized form to retain its
topological properties. Putting the two ideas together seriously, we show all
interesting properties of a chiral Chern-Simons theory are reproduced in an
explicitly regularized manner on the lattice. These include the bosonic and
fermionic level quantization, the bulk and chiral edge spectrum, the Wilson
loop flux attachment (with point-split framing or geometric framing depending
on the Maxwell coupling), the Wilson loop spin, the ground state degeneracy,
and, most non-trivially, the chiral gravitational anomaly.
